text: , also sometimes romanized as Kan'ō, was a Japanese era name (年号, nengō, lit. year name) of the Northern Court during the Nanboku-chō period after Jōwa and before Bunna. This period started in February 1350 and ended in September 1352.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric et al. (2005). "Kannō" in Japan encyclopedia, p. 474. The emperor in Kyoto was .Nussbaum, "Sukō Tennō," p. 991; Titsingh, Isaac. (1834). Annales des empereurs du japon, pp. 298-302. Sukō's Southern Court rival in Yoshino during this time was .Nussbaum, "Go-Murakami Tennō," p. 257. ==Events of the Kannō era == * 1350 (Kannō 1, 10th month): Yoshinori guarded Kyoto.Titsingh, p. 299. * 1350-1352 (Kannō 2-3): Armed conflict, variously known as the or Kannō no Juran.Nussbaum, "Kannō no Juran," p. 474. * 1352 (Enbun 3, 2nd month): Emperor Go-Murakami captured former-emperors Kōgon, Kōmyō and Sukō; and they were permitted to return to Kyoto in 1357 (Enbun 2, 2nd month).Titsingh, p. 303. ==Southern Court nengō== * Shōhei, 1346–1370 ==Related pages== * Muromachi period ==References== ==Other websites== * National Diet Library, "The Japanese Calendar" -- historical overview plus illustrative images from library's collection Kannō 1st 2nd 3rd 1350 1351 1352 Preceded by: Jōwa Northern Court nengō: Kannō Succeeded by: Bunna Category:Japanese eras Category:1350s establishments in Japan Category:1350s disestablishments in Japan
title: Kannō
